1680/A0/06/102/004.indicator_name: Number of reported cases of crimes against children.
1680/A0/06/102/004.headline: UNICEF supported study on domestic violence showcased prevailing acceptance of violence as a discipline mechanism. Another study highlighted the extreme vulnerability of children to the online sexual violence.  Human Trafficking for sexual exploitation study revealed that the profit reaches US$1.6 billion annually  and 57% of the victims are children.

1680/A0/06/102/003.headline: UNICEF contributed to the creation of Criminal Unit for Investigation of Sexual Violence and Child Abuse in Ministry of Interior  and helped Attorney General&#39 s Office (MP) to open a new Prosecution Office for Crimes against Children. UNICEF also support multiple courts that deals with cases of violence against children.

1680/A0/06/102/003.status_value: The institutions received training and in many cases  necessary equipment/installation. Additional efforts need to be made to fully implement the measures to prevent re-victimization.

1680/A0/06/104/002.indicator_name: Number of midwives certified as breastfeeding and prenatal care promoters
1680/A0/06/104/002.headline: BFHI was implemented at multiple sectors  including midwives and private sectors. UNICEF worked with PAHO to eliminate the risk of vaccine associated paralytic polio by supporting the transition from tOPVs to bivalent vaccine.  Community-based HIV screening model demonstrated promising results to expand the coverage in rural areas.

1680/A0/06/103/002.indicator_name: % of SMC lead by women in priority areas
1680/A0/06/103/002.headline: UNICEF supported 2 000 indigenous women to participate in the decision making process at school management committee. Their engagement went beyond the SMC to the MoE and the Congress for greater opportunities of participation at broader context. They used community radios to influence others on girls' education  bilingual education  among others.

1680/A0/06/103/003.headline: UNICEF continued to support monitoring network which contributed to reduction of school failure rate. To promote regular attendance to school in safe environment  UNICEF worked with strategic actors to generate social movement (Voices Movement) to prevent violence against children. Mobile application was developed to facilitate reporting the risk situations.

1680/A0/05/488/001.status_value: UNICEF supported the Ministry of Education in developing a communication strategy to promote daily reading. A nationwide mass media reading campaign will be launched soon. UNICEF has supported putting in place ministerial policy for 30 minutes of reading in every classroom  a monitoring system  delivery of an annual package of reading books to all public schools and a book take-home system.  The monitoring system revealed that in 97% of the 10 000 primary schools 30 minutes reading time had been
1680/A0/05/488/001.indicator_name: % of children who know the importance of reading at least 30 minutes daily

1680/A0/05/488/001.status_value: Within the C4D efforts  UNICEF has promoted at community level exclusive breastfeeding in health centres and among pregnant adolescents in 200 municipalities prioritised in the PHC. UNICEF has initiated a local monitoring system to track different infant and young child feeding behaviours in all these municipalities ¿ functioning in 20 of the 200 so far. 27.4% of pregnant women or with children under-2 years know about exclusive breastfeeding.
1680/A0/05/488/001.indicator_name: % of women between 10 and 18 years old who know about exclusive breastfeeding

1680/A0/05/488/001.status_value: At least 65 municipalities have work plans to reduce violence against children. All have also allocated funds for implementing their plans.
1680/A0/05/488/001.indicator_name: Level of public discussion and awareness of the lack of protection of childhood and adolescence in 40 municipalities and 8 regional capitals.

1680/A0/05/488/001.status_value: UNICEF has supported the Government in the design and implementation of the derivation route of pregnant girls under 14. Also  UNICEF supported the Government in its public campaign ¿Protect from pregnancy¿ to prevent early pregnancy by influencing social norms. On numbers of pregnant girls  cases are rising  at least partially due to improved reporting and registration systems.
1680/A0/05/488/001.indicator_name: It reduces the number of girls aged 10 to 14 years pregnant.

1680/A0/05/488/001.status_value: UNICEF has supported the implementation of the national Zero Hunger Plan  in which one of the ten interventions is related to hand-washing and hygiene measures to reduce chronic malnutrition. UNICEF has worked on `healthy schools' in which girls  boys and adolescents know and apply hygiene measures to maintain adequate health. No data is available on the specified indicator  but a similar one indicates that 65% of children  adolescents and women know and practice hygiene measures in priority com
1680/A0/05/488/001.indicator_name: % of children and adolescents who know the benefit of personal hygiene and hand washing
% of public services suitable for indigenous cultures by language and resolution practices.

Number of communication strategies conducted for the general public  children and adolescents about teen pregnancy prevention  hygiene practices  breastfeeding  educational quality and lack of protection of vulnerabilities children.

1680/A0/05/488/002.status_value: Indicators of childhood and adolescence for vital statistics  education and adolescent girls was updated in 2014. The information on the platform online (DevInfo version 7) was not placed due to technical problems. In 2015  staff of National Statistics Institute  INE  will be trained and advised by InfoLAC Panama.
1680/A0/05/488/002.indicator_name: Database of children and adolescents in the DevInfo platform updated to 2014.

1680/A0/05/488/002.status_value: The Human Rights Ombudsman  PDH  within the 25 years of the CRC  elaborated the 2014 progress report of the 2010 recommendations of the Committee on the Rights of the Child in Guatemala.
1680/A0/05/488/002.indicator_name: Progress reports of the recommendations of the Committee on the Rights of the Child.

1680/A0/05/488/002.status_value: The expected studies to realise with ICEFI were concluded (3). Of the remaining studies  surveys and publications under the IMEP 2014 two of four were finalised. The total planned studies for 2914 were seven  five of them were completed.
1680/A0/05/488/002.indicator_name: Studies and researches to overcome knowledge gaps in main issues of development  social protection  adolescents and inequities.

1680/A0/05/488/002.status_value: Twelve monthly reports were prepared (January to December 2014) on budget implementation by institution and subject  by children and adolescence public investment  by programs and activities to reduce malnutrition  and by activities of security and justice.
1680/A0/05/488/002.indicator_name: Program and activities budget implementation reports related to nutrition  investment in children  security and justice.
Number of public policies and programs M&E systems on child issues working.

1680/A0/05/485/001.indicator_name: % of children using an improved drinking water source
% of mothers and fathers who use water and soap to appropriate hand wash

1680/A0/05/485/001.status_value: 65 per cent in the priority communities.
1680/A0/05/485/001.indicator_name: % of children  adolescents and women who know and practice hygiene measures

1680/A0/05/485/001.status_value: 52 per cent. This is national level data from the health services and does not reflect the data from 166 municipalities prioritized in the Zero Hunger Plan.
1680/A0/05/485/001.indicator_name: % of mothers and fathers who know and apply appropriate hand wash techniques

1680/A0/05/485/001.status_value: No data available for national level.
1680/A0/05/485/001.indicator_name: % of schools in rural areas that have improved their water and sanitation services

1680/A0/05/485/002.status_value: 58 per cent of mothers receive breastfeeding counselling. UNICEF contributed to adapt the BFHI for midwives  who are providing breastfeeding counseling to 5 500 mothers In health services
1680/A0/05/485/002.indicator_name: % of mothers who receive appropriate attention and guidance from midwives about the essential newborn care and breastfeeding in priority municipalities

1680/A0/05/485/002.status_value: 33 per cent of mothers receive appropriate nutrition care. 83.6 per cent of children under-5 receive sprinkles and 92 per cent have Growth Monitoring Control.
1680/A0/05/485/002.indicator_name: % of mothers and children who receive appropiate nutritional attention from Health Services (at 3 attention levels) in priority municipalities

1680/A0/05/485/002.status_value: 50 per cent of the priority municipalities received supply items.
1680/A0/05/485/002.indicator_name: % of Health Services that have the neccesary equipment and tools to provide a complete and appropriate attention to pregnant women  children and adolescents in priority municipalities
% of services that apply adequately the logistic chain for essential materials
% of midwives who have knowledge adapted on newborn care and breastfeeding

1680/A0/05/485/002.status_value: The MoRES analysis indicates that only 1% of mothers surveyed in the 8 prioritised muncipalities retain some knowledge on breastfeeding.  At present midwives have little knowledge on breastfeeding (44% with adequate knowledge) and lack skills to promote it at the local level. Therefore  a new strategy for creating "Breastfeeding Friendly Midwives" is being created with the MoH and UNFPA.
1680/A0/05/485/002.indicator_name: % of mothers who receive appropriate attention and guidance from midwives about the essential newborn care and breastfeeding

1680/A0/05/485/002.status_value: Average coverage of health and nutrition interventions is still 25%.  Support has been provided to the MoH in both training and provision of inputs.  Coverage information system has been improved including maps at Municipal level.
1680/A0/05/485/002.indicator_name: % of mothers and children who receive appropiate nutritional attention from Health Services (at 3 attention levels)

1680/A0/05/485/002.status_value: Only 18 % of health services have adequate equipment to provide appropriate health and nutrition care. Supplements and anthropometric equipment  as well as some basic inputs have been provided in prioritized heath areas. Availability of inputs is considered a bottleneck and will be addressed.
1680/A0/05/485/002.indicator_name: % of Health Services that have the neccesary equipment and tools to provide a complete and appropriate attention to pregnant women  children and adolescents

1680/A0/05/485/003.indicator_name: % of health services that apply rapid test of HIV

1680/A0/05/485/003.status_value: The data available from December 2013 indicates 21.6 per cent but that is based on an estimated number of HIV-positive women. Given that fewer than 50 per cent of pregnant women are tested the estimated number of HIV-positive women could be greatly distorted.  Regardless  the country faced multiple obstacles to achieve the planned target such as no universal screening for HIV in pregnant women  limitation in timely referral of women to comprehensive care units  and lack of continuity in adherenc
1680/A0/05/485/003.indicator_name: % of pregnant women HIV positive who receives ARVs therapy

1680/A0/05/485/003.status_value: 45.6 per cent as of December 2013. Reasons for not achieving the proposed goals include the low coverage of pre-natal care  regular stock-out of the test kit and that that the strategy of elimination of vertical transmission of HIV  congenital syphilis and hepatitis B  has not been made visible.
1680/A0/05/485/003.indicator_name: % of pregnant women who have access to HIV rapid test

1680/A0/05/485/003.status_value: 80 per cent of children of HIV positive women are receiving treatment with TMP-SMZ in 16 HIV/ AIDS integral care units.
1680/A0/05/485/003.indicator_name: % of children and newborn child of women HIV positive that have access to prevention with cotrimoxazole

1680/A0/05/485/005.status_value: In 166 Municipalities priority by the Zero Hunger Plan  chronic malnutrition decreased by 1.7 percentage points (from 59.9 per cent to 58.2 per cent) according to the Zero Hunger Plan Monitoring System.
1680/A0/05/485/005.indicator_name: % of children under 5 who suffer chronic malnutrition in 166 municipalities
% of children under 2 years of age and pregnant women who benefit from the interventions of the "1 000 days window of opportunity
1680/A0/05/485/005.baseline_value: 35% for chlidren under 2. 35% for pregnant women

1680/A0/05/485/005.status_value: In 8 prioritized municipalities chronic malnutrition is 69.1%. Support to Zero Hunger Plan which emphasizes interventions of the 1 000 days window of opportunity. Promotion of Scaling-up Nutrition is also in place. Bottleneck analysis in the first 8 prioritized Municipalities  is redirecting interventions to reduce chronic malnutrition.
1680/A0/05/485/005.indicator_name: % of children under 5 who suffer chronic malnutrition.
% of mothers and fathers of children under 5 that have participated in the local counseling network  and also remenber and apply appropriate food and nutrition practices

1680/A0/05/485/005.status_value: Data should be available in the first quarter of 2013. Support to Zero Hunger Plan in prioritized by Municipalities. Gap identification at local level for adequate care at health services has been conducted. New strategies with midwives and pregnant adolescents are being developed.
1680/A0/05/485/005.indicator_name: % of children under 2 years of age and pregnant women who benefit from the interventions of the "1 000 days window of opportunity
% of mothers who have knowledge adapted on breastfeeding and complementary feeding
% of mothers who remember to have participate in a council group in the last quarter

1680/A0/05/487/002.status_value: 54 municipalities have incorporated adolescent and youth representatives to the municipal youth commissions and in 48 of them  adolescents are supporting CONJUVE's National Plan to prevent adolescent pregnancy
1680/A0/05/487/002.indicator_name: Number of municipalities in which adolescents have access to information on preventing adolescent pregnancy  HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases and gender violence prevention (At least 50% of the municipalities are in indigenous areas)

1680/A0/05/487/002.status_value: 48 Child Protection municipal offices have incorporated gender violence  adolescent pregnancy and child marriage as issues to address in their work plans
1680/A0/05/487/002.indicator_name: Number of municipalities which have Child Protection Offices with emphasis on preventing gender violence against adolescent indigenous and non indigenous women
At least 20 municipalities engage in changing practices and beliefs that affect adolescent girls
An initiative to increase the legal age for marriage from 14 to 18 years of age promoted

1680/A0/05/487/001.status_value: Adolescent networks are actively participating in 64 municipalities both in activities to prevent adolescent pregnancy  HIV and child marriage. In 54 municipalities youth commissions have been strengthened
1680/A0/05/487/001.indicator_name: Number of adolescent networks actively involved in proposing solutions at municipal level (at least 40% of adolescents participating in the networks are indigenous and at least 30% are women)

1680/A0/05/487/001.status_value: Two law initiatives that favour adolescent development are awaiting approval in Congress
1680/A0/05/487/001.indicator_name: Number of law initiatives introduced at legislative level to promote adolescent development and participation

1680/A0/05/487/001.status_value: 3 studies were completed: an ethnographic study on vulnerabilities affecting children  a study on investment on early childhood and an analysis of fiscal space for children and adolescent investment
1680/A0/05/487/001.indicator_name: Number of analytical reports on national investment for adolescent development (with gender and cultural analysis incorporated)
Number of municipalities in which adolescents engage with local officials to transform social norms that hinder their right to participate
Number of initiatives worked with Congress to support adolescent development and participation
Number of studies done to evidence level of public investment in adolescent development

1680/A0/05/486/006.status_value: There are three legal proposals including 1) the creation of a Child Protection Institute  2) a legal initiative of ¿protection of unaccompanied child migrants and combat against human trafficking¿  3) Ministerial agreement to create a Special Child Protection Unit in the MoE.
1680/A0/05/486/006.indicator_name: Number of laws and institutional regulations adhering to international standards (developed  approved  disseminated).

1680/A0/05/486/006.status_value: There was no legal modification made in 2014. There are Legal Initiatives but they were in the process of discussion for approval. However  UNICEF continued with technical assistance and political lobbying.
1680/A0/05/486/006.indicator_name: Levels of standardization and improvement of national legislation according to the CRC
1680/A0/05/486/006.baseline_value: Currently  75% of the legal framework and institutional regulations considered the CRC principles (Jurímetro).

1680/A0/05/486/006.indicator_name: Number of regulations developed and approved.

1680/A0/05/486/005.status_value: According to the Information  Development and Statistics Centre of Judicial Body  23 351 cases of child rights violation cases were attended. (3 509 by Justice of Peace  16 522 by Children and Adolescent Courts)
1680/A0/05/486/005.indicator_name: # of children and adolescents who received specialized treatment by the Judicial system (municipal peace judges).
1680/A0/05/486/005.baseline_value: Cases collected in children courts: 4 343 (Official source Organismo Judicial  2010)

1680/A0/05/486/005.indicator_name: Number of Courts for children and Peace Courts that apply minimum standards for the care of child victims and children in conflict with Criminal Law.

1680/A0/05/486/005.status_value: The complaints of sexual violence committed against girls and boys increased from 12 per day in 2012 to 23 per day in 2014  partly due to improved detection of cases and confidence in the system. A total of 16 522 boys and girls received special treatment in 2014 by the Judicial System. An estimated 40% are girls indicating a total of 6 609 (no sex disaggregated data is available).
1680/A0/05/486/005.indicator_name: # of girls who received specialized treatment by the Judicial system (municipal peace judges)

1680/A0/05/486/004.status_value: A total number of 2 917 cases attended  out of which 1 500 cases were attended by the 80 Municipal Child Protection Offices.  Additionally  293 cases were attended by the 14 departmental offices of SBS.
1680/A0/05/486/004.indicator_name: # Of children and adolescents who access public services of the special protection system  trough the protection offices(at municipal and departamental level)
1680/A0/05/486/004.baseline_value: 0 municipal protection offices  - 0 departmental protection offices  - 0 children served by Protection Offices

Number of technical staff assigned to Municipal Offices

1680/A0/05/486/004.status_value: UNICEF supported promoting the application of international human rights standards  with specific focus on differentiated attention to child victims of violence ¿ specifically with the Solicitor-General's Office  National Police  Public Prosecutor's Office  Health system and Penitentiary System It was developed through internal norms and training and is now being implemented. In the 10 prioritised departments  implementation is estimated to be above the 30% target. At central level  implementat

1680/A0/05/486/004.baseline_value: Lack of care standards for children captured by the protection system.

1680/A0/05/486/004.status_value: Out of 1 500 cases attended by 80 Municipal Child Protection Offices  1 135 corresponded to girls and women

1680/A0/05/486/003.indicator_name: # of municipalities that develops communication strategy.
Level of perception about the lack of protection of children at the Municipal level.

1680/A0/05/486/003.status_value: 80 municipalities with Municipal Child Protection office and integrated protection networks  have an assessment on the situation of children.

1680/A0/05/486/002.status_value: 46.33% Preliminary results from KAPs survey done in 2014 highlighted community preferences for boys schooling over girls. Additionally  families acknowledge they prefer keeping girls at home until older to protect them from the threats of walking to school alone. Economic limitations were also mentioned by parents as an obstacle for preschool enrolment.
1680/A0/05/486/002.indicator_name: % of children with access to preschool education in 60 priority municipalities
Number of early childhood alternatives being implemented in 60 priority municipalities
Number of volunteers involved in early childhood alternatives
Number of preschool policies being implemented

1680/A0/05/486/001.status_value: 66.45 Data showed an increase in the children that finish primary and almost a parity between boys and girls (66.68 and 66.21 respectively).
1680/A0/05/486/001.indicator_name: % of children that finish primary school in 60 priority municipalities

1680/A0/05/486/001.status_value: 87.51 The constant increase in the number of children that approve primary grades is a trend that should continue as the MoE takes ownership of MoRES monitoring of results of the implementation of specific interventions with teaches and parents as well as programmatic adjustments.
1680/A0/05/486/001.indicator_name: % of children that approve primary grades in 60 priority municipalities

U-Report was launched allowing the voices of youth to be heard.
